div.p: LONDON: Printed for R.B. & are to be sold in Pauls Church-yard. 1647.

div.head: THE Scots Treacherous Designes Discovered, &c.
div.p: WHat now my fine Apologizing Jockie? What? vindicating actions which might exceed the Powder-plot, and blush not? I had thought Bothell had not left brasse enough in Scotland uncoin'd, to have built a face to that Impudence, but what Wallace, a Wight, or other hardy Champion, have yee acoutred forth for this enterprize? certainly his next piece of justified Impudence will be the severall Murders of your Native Kings, together with Gouries most obedient Loyaltie towards King James. Sure this fine Rhetoricall Apology proceeded from some of Lowdens Spaniels, which with long attending on his Lordship, have lickt so much Sence from his eloquent Spittle, that they now venture to write Apologies; as for his Lordship, I beleeve he is very chary of writing for fear his hand should be guiltie of betraying his heart; but for the care of his tongue, I believe he is so much a Christian, that he believes the Lord hates a Double one; wherefore to prevent the malediction, he commonly makes use of three, one for the King, another for the Parliament, but the third for himselfe and fellow Confederates; yet all these mystically composed in one, and that closeted within the meager chops of a deceitfull Scot. But fearing lest I should be too bold with his honour, I shall returne to my businesse, which is to unravell the impudent bottome of this confident vindicator.

And first, my fine reformed Apologist makes it his businesse to
excuse his Countreymen for their Rising in Rebellious Tumults, and in Armes against the King; and then he refines and minces the name of a Rebellions Insurrection into the fine modest name of a Convening of Nobilitie and Gentry, And they, not as Souldiers in a military posture, but as humble Suppliants with a Petition to his Majestie, to have the Grievances of their Country redressed. It was a very prettie new-found way (which hath beene oft used in England since) of petitioning, to bring a Petition in their pockets and Muskets on their shoulders; yet these Babes of Grace did not appeare as Enemies or Disturbers of the Peace of the Kingdome, but to settle a safe and wel-grounded Peace here, where there had beene no Warres since their remembrance.

But it was Bishops that so troubled their peacefull Consciences, they favoured so of the Reliques of Rome; yea, the Figure of the Whore of Babylon; for they with their paintings and false dresses, which they put upon the word, tempted silly soules into captivitie; yea, they inforced the Spirit against its will; when now the blessed Covenant inforces nor compells none, but onely with a sweet sort of Gentle Imprisonment, and debarring them of their Liberties, and dispossessing them of their Estates by a Gentle way of Sequestration; but that is but the Blessed type of a hopefull Reformation, and no Inforcement. But truely, all these conven'd Saints had very good reason to be inveterate against Bishops, all severally in their particular callings. As for the Nobilitie, their cause was evident, and they ought to hate them were it but for this reason, That because the Bishops were indowed with more meanes, and assumed to themselves greater Estates by their Learning and Vertues, then many of the Nobilitie could purchase with their Salt-pans, Coale-pits, and such like Scotch Merchandize, with all their Coal-miners, and their Vices to boot.

As for the Pulpit-knocking Clergie, they must needs hate them; for before the Bishops began to Rule in Scotland, there was a tolleration of Non-sence throughout the Kingdom. When now it was not stamping, knocking, and pronouncing dreadfull damnation, that procured Mas. John A Benefice; but now before hee can be trusted with a Parsonage, he must be capable of Speaking mildsense for feare of committing violence on the Cushion; and this was sufficient to cause the Clergy to convene. Then for the plaine down-right Case-eating Blew-cap, judge you but his just cause of
convening; for before Bishops came in, then was the Bug-breeding Scotch-cloth all in fashion, from the Mightie Madam in the Matted-chamber, to Muckell Maggy on the Medden, and then could Sandies wife and his three Bearnes caddle their eighteen-pence a weeke at Spinning, but now since the Prelates brought in Idolatrous Lawne first on his sleeves, now it is growne so common, that every Gill-flirt must have a Gorget on't, and hold the wholesome and comely Scotch-cloth in disdaine. This reason I suppose sufficient for blew-breeked Jockie to convene.

But although these severall parties had so great a necessitie of convening, yet they did it not in a hostile way, for they sent not fire before them (nor altogether destruction behind them) but came in mildly with a Petition, onely indeed they were armed with Pike and Musket, Drum and Colours, but neither were their Pikes headed with fire as they might have beene, but with harmelesse Iron and Steele, and their Muskets onely loaden with compassionate Powder and mercifull Lead, and their Matches lighted but at one end, which shewed them to be no violent Enemies, but our loving Brethren and Friends, as their future actions have manifested.

And then the just Christians (if they may allow'd that name) presume to boast how exact they have beene in giving an accompt for his Majesties Revenues in Scotland, they may well say an accompt, for his Majestie scarce ever received any thing out of the Kingdome but In primis and Items for all his Revenues there, onely when he was last in Scotland, they were at the charges of sweeping Holy-Rood house at Edenburg, and new scouring the Organs in the private Cappell; but no sooner was his Majesties back turn'd towards Scotland, and he marched into England, but they most devoutely converted the Organs into most reverend and melodious, Bag-pipes and tin Spoones. Yet some of the Nobilitie were so prodigall to invite his Majestie, for whose Entertainment they most voluntarily did slay an Oxe and halfe a dozen Milch-Goates, with an old Tup Ram which served for Venison; but for this rioting, flesh was excommunicated their Kitchins for one quarter of a yeare, and the poore hungry Serving-men lived a moneth after on the steame of the Kitchin, and lickings of the Dripping-pans, and the reversions of mouldy crusts in the Pantry, and thought themselves in a continuall feast too; but in this supposed plentie they remained, till they looked like so many of Pharoah's leane Kine;
but they did not onely prognosticate a future famine, but manifest a present, which made that provident Joseph, the good Lord Argile, to Assemble his Camells, and Lesley his Asses, to fetch in Provisions from the Neighbouring Countries; but England can testifie, that it was not Provisions alone that have satisfied these beasts since they first conven'd.

Then you confesse, his Majesties Indulgent Clemency you cannot deny: In troth I wonder at it, ye being all so naturally of that trade that knowes the danger of confessing. Then you say, you went home so contentedly, hoping to live at peace and rest at home (how long thinke you yee might have staid there before yee had beene troubled by any? Sure till the last Trump blew; and 'tis a question whether yee will be taken notice on then or no: As for Heaven, ye are not so impudent to hope for it, and Hell will hardly be troubled with yee.)

But how long pray did your contented life last at home? Why, till you had spent all the monies you had of your beloved Brethren in England, for so faithfully preferring your so well Armed Petition, and that being once gone, the Bishops troubled you againe, and their Ecclesiasticall Government began to be very offensive, and the Proctors and Registers would not accept of the Humiliation of Jockie of the Bray, and Jannet of the Dale, in the Solemne stoole of Repentance, but gude feith they must pay their Siller too; which tyranny over the cod-piece and placket was never knowne before in faire Scotland; wherefore I thinke it was no more then time to convene, to extirpate these Romish Prelates. But certainly Jockie it was not thy zeale to the Kirk, nor absolutely thy envy to the Bishops, that did first induce thee to convene; but thou sawest that good King Jeamy was dead, and that his Bearne was not so easily perswaded to give what thou hadst the Impudence to aske; besides, you perceived that your double hearts and Janus faces were discovered in England, and how the most of you were baffel'd, hated, and scorn'd out of all company (which you did sufficiently merit) wherefore being conscious, you retired your selves home to your smokey Mansions, where with your ingendring with your Long-eared Priests, and mixing of Treason and Blasphemy together, you at length with much adoe brought forth and spawn'd that wholesome Monster the Covenant, whose Hydra's head did so increase by reason of the mystery of the sence of it,
the extirpating the Prelate being the pretended intention, and all assembled knowing no other intent, which being once conven'd, and in another petitionary and peacefull posture onely Armed for defence, and offence, you then not onely questioned the Prelates tyranny, as you called it, but began to limit the Kings Prerogative too, under the modest and carefull names of just Rights and Priviledges, which are as your usage hath manifested, a confining of his Majestie to one punctuall place of being; and his Priviledges to play at Goffe or Bowles when you please to give him leave. A very prettie sweet just Right and Prerogative for a Prince, and a very solemne piece to ingage a Nation to a Sacramentall Oath to maintaine their Prince in such a Prerogative.

Then after your second Qualification, O how jealous you were in raysing an Army for Ireland at your owne charges (as you call it) but it then cost the King treble the value onely towards it, (besides the accompts of his Revenues) and what service they have done there God knowes it, but no man can hardly testifie any thing of it, onely that the poore English Gentry and others that had any Estates left free from the Rebells, they wearied out of the Kingdom & Country with their heavy oppressions that they might possesse themselves of their Estates, which they have done now.

Indeed they twice besieged Charlemont, and to say truth, they were but twice beat from it; and at Black-water last yeare they had a glorious Victory, for the Lord was before them, Nay, all the Lords and Commanders they had were before them, but the Irish was in the Reare for ten miles, with the Devill to boot.

And there you complaine that your men wanted Breeches and Shoes. Why? It is not unknowne to the world, that most of your Nation, till they came into England, did scarce thinke there were any such things Incident to nature; for yee are not onely borne without Breeches and Shoes, but bred without them, and being not used to them in your Infancy, I wonder how you have the Impudence to complaine for want of them in your age?

Then thirdly, to shew your gratitude to his Majestie, and to settle him in his throne, you convened againe, for the good of the King onely now, the Bishops being all suppressed, which evidently appeared by your opposing of the Armies raised by his Majesties Command; but alas you could doe no more then you could doe, for it was against your Covenant to joyne with such wicked
persons as served the King, (besides the King had no hundred thousand pounds for you) and His Souldiers wronged the Country in taking meate for themselves of the Country, but you happy Israelites certainly lived on Celestiall Quailes and Manna, but most commonly ye found the Quailes in the Dove-Coats and Hen-Roomes, and the Manna in your Landlords Pantries, and Ambries. And as for plundering houses, you scorned it, (but what was necessary for you) but you with a religious Sacrilege fell upon Churches, not plundering them, but modestly reforming the Surplices into Sarkes and reverent Nightcaps, the Common-Prayer Booke into Tobacco Papers, and the Consecrated Chalice blessedlie reformed into a Candle-Cup for Mas. Iohn your prick-card Teacher, which he after a long Grace, devoutly drinkes some sixe times full to strengthen him in a long-winded exercise; and such hopefull Babes could no waies joyne with the Kings party without hazarding the breach of your Cordiall Covenant.

Now to your boasting: First for your battle at Marston More, I am confident your Generall cannot give an account of any thing done that day after the warning Peece was shot: for his Excellency was thirty miles from the place before the fight was done, a shifting a shirt, and bewailing the death of his deare Countrimen; And after at New-Castle where you were so mercifull, the Towne cannot but witnesse your civility in plundering, when you left not an Ale-wife a Spicket and Fosset to set up trading againe with, and there was not Canvas enough left in Towne to make a Hauking bagge, and yet the harmelesse Creatures did not plunder neither. And I beleeve the Countries can witnesse how civill you were in your march towards Hereford, when the people wrung their Bells for joy of your comming, but at your departure they wrung their hands; and I doubt not out to make up the Peale to see you wrung by the e ares for your civility: for in that march Beefe and Mutton was too grosse meat for your queasie stomachs, which were bred up with junkets of long Cale, and refined Oatemeale; and when they wanted shooes, (which they complaine of) they made bold with their Landlords Bootes, vestures that neither they, nor their Fore-fathers were guilty of wearing. But how thinke yee they came by these habiliments? why? first in their march they made Malignants, then search'd their houses for Armes, and finding such dangerous Instruments of War, as Bootes, Breeches, Coates and
Shirts, and other such offensive weapons, as by your Covenant you were bound, seized on them, this being the onely way for the setling of a well grounded Peace in both Kingdomes, and it much conducing to the Liberty of the Subject.

Then for your not thirsting after bloud, let Canfrome bee witnesse; where yee spared not the life of either man or woman, but only two old wives, who had long time beene suspected to be of the same trade that most of your mothers were of; Then when you were before Hereford, you were indeed so carefull of the quiet of the Countrey, that ye scarce left an Oxe or Sheepe within ten miles to disturbe it, or a Cock to crow, or Goose to hisse at ye, for feare of disturbing the rest and Peace of the Kingdome. Then in your march back again, I think you shewed your selves the same men that marched that waies before; for ye used the same civility.

But now my friends, for your fine usage of His Majesty a word or two, sure you cannot be so impudent, to deny but with many private Letters, and crafty Sollicitours, you were continually inviting His Majesty down to your Army, and how you used Him there I can something testifie. First you debarred admittance of any to His Majestie if he spoake any Language but the Language of the heathen your Country-men: you were so curteously obedient that you would peruse His Letters from His Queene, fearing lest there might be some French plots in them against the safety of His Majesties Person.

A Court was kept for Him, but Nebuchadnezar had as civill homage done to him in the Forrest, when he was metamorphosed, by the beasts, as you bestowed on your King at New-Castle, and his fare was of far more delicacy: yet you allowed Him meate I confesse, and it was so be cooked, that if ever the Litanie come up againe, we will have it fixed with an Imprecation to be delivered from them.

A Guard he had, but no devourers of Bull-beefe, for since their first essence they never tasted any flesh beyond Tripes and Livers; instead of the honourable badges of Yorke and Lancaster upon their backe and breasts, they wore the lively achievements of Aberdene and Dundee, with more Legions of puissant Lice traversing over their Scab-bemountaind bodies: But then to shew His Majestie the true worship of God, and the Reformed Kirk in her Glorie, O what plenty of Ionahs did the monstrous Fish, the Kirke of Scotland, vomit forth to Prophecie the destruction of great Ninivy, with the King thereof! they were daring Priests, what Pulpit Treason did they venter on? the which with his desperate knocking on the Court-Cubbord, which kept time with
his blasphemy till the whole Auditory were weary of him, all his matter being the holy Covenant; first he declares, no Covenant no Salvation, no Covenant no Peace, nay, if the King tooke it not, there could be no Government for Him nor His Kingdom, but He and His Posterity must absolutely perish; more, if He tooke not the solemne Covenant, He could never make restitution for the bloud shed in Scotland, which the Lord would require at His hands at the last day; this was not preached in a private Chappell, but openly in the Royall Presence of the King: And certainly these were seducing Motives to tempt the King to Coheare to their Reformation.

Nobility they had some which served for Court Ciphers, still watching when the King would invest them with new honours, but His Majesty thinking none merited so well as Lastly first dubd him with a Cushion, and next wit a Trencher.
The first, because out of the affection he had to His Majesty, and His Friends he proclaymed it death for any that had served in his Majesties War to stay in New-Castle.

The second, for the care he had of His Majestie by setting a double Guard at His Bed-chamber doore in New-Castle, a courteous gratitude to His Majesty for all honour imposed upon him. Nay, Scotch Leards were at the charge of putting themselves in Bootes and Hats, which thing neither they nor their Predecessors ever knew since the time of Iudas Escariot, who was the Patriarke of the Nation, And these panch-bellyed Disloyallists being big with Ambition made a journey to Court on purpose to produce a small Knighthood, which proved null; for there they stood labouring for honour (which the titurary Court Lords had promised them) taking as much paines for it, as Dametas did for the Treasure under the Stone, and to as much purpose; but for the Committee that sate there, the Contrivers of the French Massacre, nor Catesby and his confederates in the Powder Plot, were not halfe so perfidious, nor their consultations so destructive, this looked like Herods judgement Hall in the Hangings, where Louderdalle & Argile looked like the two false witnesses, whilst Lowden sate like Pontius Pylate, but with unwashed hands.

And these are they that my pretty vindicator endeavours to justifie for selling their King; but alas, they did not sell Him, they did (as the Welchman did with his Hare) if the Parliament would lend them two hundred thousand pounds, then they would lend them the King, not sell Him by any meanes; but they thought themselves not able to protect His Person from danger, therefore it was convenient He should go to a
place of more safetie, and no sooner they had their two hundred thousand pound, but they obediently told his Majestie that he must goe to his Parliament, and so left him to the conduct of I know not whom, neither did they care: But they deserved the summe of Money had the King never come to them, having had but three hundred thousand pound for the raysing and maintaining an Army of thirtie thousand men for three yeares.

Thirtie thousand men Jockie? A goodly Army, but how many of the first twentie foure thousand ranne away and durst not see the Enemy? Above ten thousand; and the last six thousand never were above foure, whereof two of them came out of Ireland; but grant you had thirtie thousand men and but this three hundred thousand pound, I hope you would be pleased to remember other triviall summes that came in by the by; as two hundred & fiftie thousand pound for Coales at Newcastle, and fifty thousand pound at Hereford, beside some such small summe at Newarke. And then free quarter was nothing; for you being bred always with Grasse, lived here upon Hay and such Rubbish, as Turkies, Capons, and Chickens, and such ordinary meat, which thousands of your Leards at home will goe fortie miles to behold and admire, and be satisfied with the sight, for tasting was beyond their hopes; then you had a pretty trick called Trencher-Mony too, the which was, 6. pence for every Landlord to pay to each Soldier, that they would be favourably pleased to undoe him.

Too many neglected Gentlemen which had beene of the Kings Party, which thought to have sheltred themselves under you in their distresse, when the King desired you to relieve them and you engaged your selves to him that you would, yet all the reliefe you did administer, was a groat a day to Gentlemen that had kept your betters to their Groomes, and this groat was exacted from the poore Countrey too, which were doubly over-burdened by you before, by your heavy Taxes and Contributions; so that ye may well bring in the North Country to be witnesses of your Civill behaviours, when you forced your poore Landlords to sell their Coats from their backs to buy sawce for their own Powltry; & for Beefe and Muttons, what yee eate not, yee sent away and carried it to Scotland, for they were all Malignants on the other side Trent; but certainly yee are much wronged and abused by many, that avouch that you will not eate Swines flesh, when the Countrey can testifie you left not Swine enough in the Countrey to evacuate enough excrement to serve your Landresses to cleanse your Linnen (that being the onely Soape they use) no there was hardly a Hogge in the Countrey but those that were
Commanders in the Army; then another very prettie trick you had, called Lift Money, which was at your departure, to inforce the Countrey to advance you ten dayes pay for your march home, besides the loane of their Horses (the which they might safely have taken a solemne leave off) to carry the goods with which you (I will not say did Plunder) but had use for in England; but I must be so uncivill to say, that verily you did as it were Plunder in Carlile; for where many families had left the Towne because their houses were infected, you being fill'd with the Spirit, according to the measure of grace the Devill had left you, most faire and honestly opened the windowes of the said houses, and in your care brought forth the goods, carrying them to Scotland to be aired and cleansed, where God was so just to punish you with the disease you Plundred from Carlile; and this is part of the faire and civill carriages that my fine Apologist undertakes to vindicate; had his cause beene mine I should soone have relinquished it with shame, but in discovering his fathers and brethrens nakednesse, he doth perfectly demonstrate his and their Geneology to be derived from the loines of cursed Ham.

Then in your future intentions, how jealous you would faine seeme to be for the true worship of God, when it is not unknowne to the world, whom yee call for witnesse of your integritie, that you are the greatest hypocrites in it: And you know, that through all the world yee are branded with the name of false-hearted Scots; and surely you are a blessed sweet people, and very likely to make a happy Reformation; And certainly we ought to hazard our Lives and Estates for the accomplishment of it. And then you protest, that if any shall intrench on his Majesties just Rights and Priviledges, to settle him in his throne again: Good Jockie, who were they that first troubled him in it? And how many Fast and Loose Tricks have you shew'd him since? And thinke you his Majestie will trust to you now? No surely, the King hath had tryall enough of your fidelitie already, and the Kingdome of your civilitie and kindnesse: From which, with your farther assistance, Good Lord deliliver us.

And Now I hope I have discovered the Scot according to my weake abilitie; but what is done is nothing but what is veritie and cleare from malice, but very neere to the true colours of their actions past: For those to come, I feare I must leave to be sensured by the judicious; and for this time, goe no farther then my owne knowledge.
